history.content:
I know for certain you don't need to have completed lower division major requirements.

I'm not sure if you need junior standing, nor how strictly that's enforced for EECS UGSIs.

Here are the requirements to be considered for a UGSI position: 

Undergraduate GSIs

In order to apply to be a UGSI, you must meet the following qualifications:

  1. Be in good academic standing (i.e., cannot be on academic probation or have more than 2 incomplete grades)
  2. Enrolled in the minimum number of units approved by your college by the second week of classes (this is a week before the regular campus deadline)
  3. Upper Division status when you begin teaching
  4. Overall GPA of 3.0 or higher and maintain this GPA in the semester you are teaching
  5. Previously taken the course, its equivalent or a more advanced course, with a grade of A- or better
  6. Complete the 300-level semester-long pedagogical seminar on teaching in the first semester you are teaching
  7. First-time UGSIs must attend the Teaching Conference before the beginning of the teaching semester.
  8. First-time UGSIs must complete the GSI Professional Standards and Ethics Online Course by the first day of classes.
  9. If you are an international student and this will be your first time being a UGSI, you must complete the Language Proficiency Screening Questionnaire. (Please notify Patrick Hernan at hernan@eecs.berkeley.edu once you have completed the questionnaire.)
  10. If you wish to GSI during the Summer Session and you are a graduating senior, you must postpone your graduation to August in order to be eligible for a Summer GSI-ship.

children.subject: I'm going to assume Junior standing on CalCentral (60+ units), but someone correct me if I'm wrong.
What constitutes Upper Division status (from"3. Upper Division status when you begin teaching")?

history.content: In order to be considered for a UGSI position, do we need to have completed the lower division major requirements, or do we just need junior standing in terms of units(including AP)?
history.subject: UGSI Upper Division Requirement
